docs.lead_paragraph: About this time last year, rumors were rampant that Anatoly F. Dobrynin would be returning to Moscow after 21 years as the Soviet Ambassador to the United States. Well, a year has passed and the rumors have stopped. Mr. Dobrynin, the dean of the diplomatic corps, a solicitous, 64-year- old grandfather whose 13-year-old grandaughter lives with him, is nearing his 22d anniversary here. And he is in a relaxed mood about everything except the state of Soviet- American relations.

headline.main: INSIDE SOVIET EMBASSY WITH DEAN OF DIPLOMATS

docs.lead_paragraph: News Analysis The revised ''Baby Doe'' regulation issued this week by the Reagan Administration will limit Federal intervention at hospitals in the care and treatment of newborns with birth defects. The new regulation, announced by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Margaret M. Heckler, and Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, creates advisory review committees within each hospital. It is a major shift in the way the Federal Government has been dealing with handicapped infants, and it is to take effect in 30 days, on Feb. 11. Had such an infant-care review committee been in place at University Hospital at Stony Brook, L.I., where a girl born with severe birth defects three months ago is under care, Dr. Koop said, it is unlikely the Government would have taken the unusual step of going to Federal court to get her medical records.

headline.main: LETTING PANELS DECIDE THE FATE OF DEFECTIVE INFANTS

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST September, the parents of Baby Jane Doe put the finishing touches on a new room designed for their first baby. They never dreamed, they said, that their newborn would be so severely ill that in all likelihood she would never come home. Nor were they prepared for the fact that their daughter, born Oct. 11 in Suffolk County, would become the subject of an unusual Federal suit by the Justice Department that may yet be decided by the United States Supreme Court. Almost from the day she was born, the little girl's fate has been the center of a dispute involving right-to-life groups, the Vatican, the Reagan Administration and advocates for the handicapped on one side, and the parents, state courts and the State Attorney General on the other. The legal battle has taken various turns since A. Lawrence Washburn, an avowed right-to-life lawyer, went to State Supreme Court in Suffolk shortly after the infant was born. Mr. Washburn wanted the courts to overturn the decision of the parents to oppose surgery for their daughter.

headline.main: BABY DOE: HARD CASE FOR PARENTS AND COURTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Harris Brotman is a Chicago-based writer with a doctorate in genetics. By Harris Brotman NY DAY NOW, A BABY IS EXPECTED to be born in California who will be the first in the world to owe its life to a procedure known as human embryo transfer. A few weeks later, another California baby is expected to become the second example of this newest method of providing children to couples unable to conceive them naturally. Neither child will be genetically related to the woman who will give it birth. Each baby was conceived within the body of another woman altogether, an ''ovum donor,'' and is the result of the union of its father's sperm and the donor's egg. After five days within the donor's uterus, at a time when it consisted of only 80 to 100 cells arranged in a fluid-filled sphere, each embryo was removed by a process known as lavage, or ''washing out,'' and then placed within the infertile womb of its father's wife, where it developed normally.
